awd_titl_txt: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Linking turbulent flow dynamics to meandering river migration
awd_abstract_narration:
Rivers are central conduits for life in the US. They are thoroughfares for shipping, focal points for infrastructure and manufacturing, and oases for recreation and wildlife. Rivers often migrate as a natural process, one which has far-reaching consequences: it poses hazards to bridges and other infrastructure; shifts flooding patterns; and over geologic time, shapes underground resources, including groundwater and hydrocarbons. This project advances the field of Earth-surface science by building new tools to forecast river migration and a new, related curriculum for college science classes. The project will further diversity in the sciences by supporting a team of women and men from the mountain west to the east coast, who together represent two state universities and one Tribal College.

A foundation of the research is a new set of state-of-the-art mathematical simulations using higher-performance computing techniques. These simulations will capture interactions between water flow and sediment transport across an unprecedented range of river shapes. Model predictions will be tested and refined using experiments in a scale model of a meandering river, and by comparison to geologic data sets. The research findings will help geologists, engineers, and river scientists to mitigate river hazards, manage wildlife habitat, and identify natural resources spanning the changing landscapes of the nation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
Rivers are central conduits for life in the US. They are thoroughfares for shipping, focal points for infrastructure and manufacturing, and oases for recreation and wildlife. Rivers often migrate as a natural process, one which has far-reaching consequences: it poses hazards to bridges and other infrastructure; shifts flooding patterns; and over geologic time, shapes underground resources, including groundwater and hydrocarbons.

 Intellectual Merit

The research has yielded new knowledge regarding the structure of turbulent flow in meandering rivers; relationships between turbulent flow, sediment transport, and bank erosion in laboratory meanders; and new knowledge regarding spatial and temporal patterns of meandering river migration over decadal timescales. Together, these findings impact river science on a range of timescales of interest for both engineering and geological issues. The experimental methods for studying bank erosion document a novel approach to these experiments that will be reproducible by researchers in geomorphology and civil engineering. The research has also enhanced the usability of an existing, historical dataset for meandering river migration in the US. This freely available dataset of historic river migration provides practitioners in river restoration a new reference dataset for historic river behavior since the early 20th century for 89 rivers in the US.

 Broader Impacts

Rivers are major hubs for society and ecology. The fundamental research supported by this work can contribute directly to sustainable management of natural resources and design of engineered structures in riparian ecosystems. The project is also supported the professional development of an undergraduate and a graduate student in preparation for leadership roles in a STEM field and supported new and collaborative hands-on river meandering educational activities in collegiate hydrology courses.

 


Last Modified: 04/21/2025
Modified by: Jessica L Kozarek
